Hariz Arthur Maloy, Independent Financial Advisor at Promiseland IndependentTop Contributor (Sep)Level 9. God of WisdomAnswered on 12 Jun 2019It costs $2 everytime you buy SSB. And even if a new rate is launched, you can liquidate your current bond and buy the new one if you want. So just go for a lumpsum.0 comments2

Gabriel Tham, Kenichi Tag Team Member at Tag TeamLevel 8. WizardAnswered on 12 Jun 2019Depends on how much is your lump sum. It will save you the costs and trouble of applying every month.But if you are trying to create a bond ladder for DBS multiplier, you can buy for 6 months. This ensure you get 12 months consistent payouts that counts as investment category.The maximum for SSB is 200k per NRIC. So, you can put in a lump sum first, then do 1k a month till you hit the 200k. After that, you can start to optimize by withdrawing the lower interest rate ones and putting into higher interest rate SSB issues.0 comments1

Vincent Tan Wen Bin, Assistant Vice President at Thinkers AllianceLevel 5. GeniusAnswered on 12 Jun 2019If we are talking about SSB, I would put a lump sum. Since capital is guaranteed, there isn't a need to dollar cost average. However it will be a different story if we are talking about assets like stocks, funds, etfs etc. These are assets that will move in price and I will dollar cost average if I find that the prices are on the higher side.0 comments0
